user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SymbolLookup_Static:
```c
int32 OS_SymbolLookup_Static(cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName, const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list --
             * Return "OS_ERROR" to indicate that an actual search was done
             * with a not-found result, vs. not searching at all. */
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }
        if (strcmp(StaticSym->Name, SymbolName) == 0 &&
            (ModuleName == NULL || strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0))
        {
            /* found matching symbol */
            *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)StaticSym->Address;
            return_code    = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are present in the shown code. I inspected the entire function for common vendor extensions such as GCC/Clang attributes or keywords (__attribute__, __asm__, __extension__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline assembly, and nonstandard storage-class specifiers) and found none. The identifiers like int32, cpuaddr, OS_static_symbol_record_t and OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE are project typedefs/macros (standard C preprocessor and typedef usage, not language extensions) and casts such as (cpuaddr) are standard C. Standard library function strcmp and NULL are used. Pointer arithmetic (++StaticSym), control-flow constructs (while, if, break), and comments are all standard C. If there are concerns about any macros or typedefs introducing compiler-specific extensions (for example if OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE expands to something with __attribute__ or a compiler pragma), that expansion is not shown here — the present code fragment does not itself contain any explicit language extensions that must be investigated under MISRA C:2023 Rule 1.2.
